questions.question_text: Which of the following VPN types provides the highest security for a user who travels often but also has the highest bandwidth requirements to provide a satisfactory user experience?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A Full-tunnel VPN provides the highest security for a user who travels often while also offering the highest bandwidth requirements for a satisfactory user experience.

Explanation:
Full-tunnel VPN: In a full-tunnel VPN configuration, all of the user's internet traffic, regardless of destination, is routed through the VPN tunnel to the corporate network. This ensures that all communication is encrypted and secured, even when the user is accessing the internet from public or untrusted networks. While this level of security is ideal for protecting sensitive data, it can result in higher bandwidth usage due to routing all traffic through the VPN.

Benefits of Full-tunnel VPN for the scenario described:
Highest Security: All traffic is encrypted and protected, making it the most secure option for users who frequently travel and connect to various networks, including public Wi-Fi.

Selected Answer: D
full tunnel has exceptionally lower throughput than split tunnel because the data goes through a next gen firewall. NGFW does deep packet inspection which is very compute expensive, and thus the bandwidth drops a huge amount.

Selected Answer: D
Bandwith ist the keyword.

Initially I thought full tunnel as it is the most secure, however it says "BUT also has the highest bandwidth requirements". 

Full tunnel leads to slower speeds as it requires ALL of your data to be encrypted, therefore I'm going with D.

Selected Answer: D
Split tunneling allows you to increase speed while encrypting specific data. This would provide a satisfactory user experience while encrypting corporate data. Which would also satisfy the second portion of the question.

https://www.fortinet.com/resources/cyberglossary/vpn-split-tunneling

Selected Answer: A
A. Full-tunnel provides Maximum security

comments.content: it says THE MOST SECURE and full tunnel is the most secure here. It is not B. because it does not mention anything about sites and C. doesn't make sense. Like you said split-tunnel allows non company traffic to go through which makes it less secure then full tunnel

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Split tunneling 
Company traffic goes through company
non company traffic goes through local connection (Zoom, Youtube etc...)

Fastest and Secure

Selected Answer: A
Paths = Routes

Selected Answer: A
A. traceroute

To map the path of a PC to the router, a technician should use the "traceroute" tool. Traceroute is a network diagnostic tool that displays the route and measuring transit delays of packets across an Internet Protocol (IP) network. It helps identify the routers or hops that a packet traverses from the source to the destination, allowing the technician to map the network path.

The other options are useful for different network diagnostic purposes:
- Ping (option B) is used to test the reachability of a host on an Internet Protocol (IP) network.
- Ifconfig (option C) is used to configure network interfaces on a Unix or Linux system.
- Netstat (option D) displays network connections, routing tables, interface statistics, masquerade connections, etc., on a Unix or Windows system.

questions.question_text: A technician needs to map the path of a PC to the router. Which of the following tools should the technician use to accomplish this task?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. A duplicate IP address is on the network.

Selected Answer: A
A. A duplicate IP address is on the network.

The most likely cause of the issue described is that a duplicate IP address exists on the network. When the user manually sets the IP address on the device, and that IP address is already assigned to another device (due to the DHCP lease), conflicts can arise. This can result in intermittent connectivity issues, connection timeouts, and network disruptions.
Manual errors cause lots of duplicate addresses

Selected Answer: A
If a host gets a duplicate IP but its OS doesn't detect it, you'll see a valid address assignment, but network connectivity will just not work, or at best will be intermittent.

Selected Answer: C
Bard said C is the answer.
When a device is configured with a manual IP address, it must also be configured with the subnet mask for the network. The subnet mask tells the device which IP addresses are on the same network as it. If the subnet mask is incorrect, then the device will not be able to communicate with other devices on the network. << is it correct?

comments.content: This wouldnt cause intermittent connectivity, it just wouldnt work at all.

questions.question_text: A company is using a DHCP server with 12-hour leases for its device configurations. A user records the information that the DHCP server provides and uses the information to connect a device with a manual IP set. Over time, the user experiences intermittent connectivity and recurring connection timeouts. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of the issue?

choices.C: The device is set to use an incorrect subnet.
choices.D: The device is set to use an incorrect gateway.
choices.B: The user's device is pointing to an incorrect DNS server.
choices.A: A duplicate IP address is on the network.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Tamper detection refers to any method that alerts you when a device
or the enclosure in which it resides has been opened or an attempt has
been made to open it.

Selected Answer: D
D. Tamper detection

Selected Answer: D
D. Tamper detection

Selected Answer: D
Tamper detection: Tamper detection refers to the implementation of sensors, alarms, or other mechanisms to detect unauthorized physical access or tampering with assets or equipment. In this case, the networked sensor installed on the server rack door is designed to detect if the door is opened without proper authorization and send an alert to notify relevant personnel.

The other options mentioned have different meanings:

A. Cipher lock: A cipher lock is a type of lock that requires a numeric code or password to gain access. It is a form of access control, but it does not necessarily involve detecting unauthorized access or tampering.

Selected Answer: D
The technician installed a tamper detection sensor. Tamper detection sensors are designed to detect and alert when an unauthorized attempt is made to access or move a protected asset. In this case, the sensor sends an alert when the server rack door is opened, allowing the technician to monitor and respond to any unauthorized access to the data center server rack.

Selected Answer: A
In some models, the lock mechanism may also trigger an alarm or notification to alert security personnel or the owner of the lock. https://www.velocenetwork.com/tech/what-is-a-cipher-lock/

questions.question_text: A technician is concerned about unauthorized personnel moving assets that are installed in a data center server rack. The technician installs a networked sensor that sends an alert when the server rack door is opened. Which of the following did the technician install?

An administrator is preparing an organization for a potential disaster. The administrator configures the network switches and turns off the equipment in a data center. Which of the following is this scenario an example of?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Cold site don't have any hardware

Selected Answer: A
The question implies that the switches are already in situ. If some of the hardware is on site already then this is a warm site.

When it comes to disaster sites an easy way I remember the difference is thinking of turkey Scenario.

You are in charge of bringing the turkey to Thanksgiving, but you are also a cuts. You have 4 options on how to prepare
Cold turkey- it's sitting in your freezer and but it's not prepared 

Warm turkey- it's has most of the hard prep work don't just needs to be reheated

Hot turkey- you made and brought an entire second turkey expressly for this Scenario.

Cloud turkey- you buy a Togo turkey

Selected Answer: A
another badly worded question but it's a warm site. all configured then powered off, only to be spun up in a disaster. cold site has nothing in place.

Selected Answer: A
Cold just means infrastructure (rent of a place) with no actual networking equipment inside

Selected Answer: A
A. Switches were configured before turning off.

Selected Answer: A
A. Warm site

Selected Answer: D
cant be cold site for obvious reasons. but cannot be warm site either. the technician is simply configuring routers (possibly to point to the hot site) he is NOT moving the current data set which would be required for a warm site.
A warm site takes 2-4 days to setup, this matches the time for a turned off switch network to boot up properly

Selected Answer: A
a cold site equipment is not powered on or CONFIGURED. The tech configured the switch and then turned it off so therefor it is a warm site since he configured the switch

Selected Answer: B
The answer is B. Cold site.
This is a warm site? from my understanding a cold site doesn't have any equipment in it.

comments.content: You literally posted saying a cold site equipment is not powered on or CONFIGURED. The tech configured the switch then turned it off so therefor it is a warm site since he configured the switch.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Cold site: A cold site is a type of disaster recovery solution where a physical location is established to restore IT operations in the event of a disaster. However, the cold site is not fully operational or equipped with active systems. Instead, it provides the necessary physical infrastructure, such as space, power, and cooling, but the equipment is not powered on or configured. In case of a disaster, organizations would need to install and configure their hardware and systems at the cold site before resuming operations.

In the scenario, the administrator is preparing for a potential disaster by configuring the network switches and having the equipment turned off. This aligns with the concept of a cold site, as the site is prepared but not fully operational until needed.
